Proposal Title: Electrochromic Variable Emissivity Devices for Thermal Control
Small Business Concern_Address: Tampa , FL33710 - 9998, Eclipse Energy Systems, Inc.
Principal Investigator_Name: In Phase II of this effort, samples of the electrochromic devices will be tested to determine their tolerance to high vacuum, UV light, and bombardment with energetic oxygen ions. The design will be optimized to improve performance, reliability, and durability in the space environment.
Principal Investigator_Address: Nick Kislov, PhD, Eclipse Energy Systems, Inc.
Technical Abstract: Significant modulation of solar reflectance, solar absorption, and IR emissivity can be achieved with electrochromic devices operating at very low voltages. They use very little energy and can maintain their state of solar reflectance, solar absorption, and IR emissivity for some time after the potential has been removed. Devices fabricated as a monolithic stack of solid state inorganic materials can withstand the harsh space environment. These kinds of Variable Electrochromic Devices (VEDs), with no moving parts, are well suited for active thermal control of spacecraft.
Potential non-NASA applications: The Phase I effort will produce 100cm2 VEDs on thin metal substrates with an areal density, for the electrochromic film stack, of 7g/m2 and modulations of emittance from 0.1 to 0.5 and solar absorptance from 0.2 to 0.8. The optical, thermal, and electrical performance of these devices will be characterized. A detailed calculation  will be performed to predict thermal performance of  these electrochromic coatings.

Proposal Title: High-Frequency Low-Temperature Regenerative Heat Exchangers
Small Business Concern_Address: 3001 Redhill Ave, Bldg 4, Costa Mesa , CA   92869 - 4529
Principal Investigator_Address: 3001 Redhill Ave, Bldg 4, Costa Mesa , CA92869 - 4529
Technical Abstract: Even with multi-layer insulation blankets, cryogenic thermal switches, thermal distribution systems (such as cryogenic heat pipes), and advanced thermal/structural isolation systems, the mission capability of a fully-passive, stored cryogen system is compromised by the lack of an active cooler to recharge the system.  This shortcoming is particularly acute at very low temperatures (<15 K) because there are no proven, long-life space cryocooler technologies for that operational temperature range.  The primary technological barrier to extending proven Stirling and pulse tube technologies down to liquid helium temperatures is the absence of a regenerator design that will function at the high frequencies (> 30 Hz) required to enable small, compact designs typical of existing flexure-bearing, space-qualified cryocoolers.  Irvine Sensors Corporation proposes to develop an advanced regenerator, based upon the use of novel rare earth metal matrix designs to enable very-low-temperature Stirling and pulse tube cryocoolers for both ground and space applications.  The matrix will offer the combined benefits of low porosity and an extremely high surface-area-to-volume ratio, both of which are essential for very low temperature operation.  Our goal is to achieve a 50 percent improvement in efficiency for high-frequency regenerators operating around a cold head temperature of 5 K.
Potential non-NASA applications: The proposed regenerator has broad application for virtually any cryogenic refrigeration need below 15 K.  It will reduce size and mass and increase reliability of the cryocooler required for cooling the switch core of a low-temperature superconducting router being developed by ISC for the Internet backbone.  The SuperRouter? architecture is being defined to ultimately provide Internet message routing at a rate of 1E11 bits/s, which is a virtually impossible goal to achieve with conventional electronics or even optical solutions.  These routers are estimated to represent a $70M/yr. cryocooler business.  The proposed concept will offer improved efficiency, even for traditional 4 K Gifford-McMahon refrigerators, because of increased control over matrix porosity and a reduced pressure drop through the parallel plate matrix.  Magnetic resonance imaging, cryogenic vacuum pumping systems, laboratory instruments, radio astronomy, etc. comprise a potential $21M annual commercial market.  This projection is believed to be conservative in that the advent of compact, long-life 4 K cryocoolers will enable applications that are unforeseen at this time.

Proposal Title: Extended range profiling
Technical Abstract: The innovation is a new, non-contact approach for sensing the local surface height of an optic.  It offers an unprecedented combination of features: (1) sub-nanometer sensitivity and accuracy without calibration; (2) large dynamic range (several mm or more); and (3) accommodates large surface slopes and structure.  The proposed approach vastly increases the dynamic range of conventional focusing interferometers and yet the sensitivity and accuracy are preserved at their sub-nanometer level.  In a secondary innovation, an optical aberration is added to enlarge the focused spot on the test piece for immunity to surface defects.  The aberration is exactly cancelled on the return trip from the test piece, thus maintaining wavefront quality and measurement accuracy.  These innovations can greatly improve the optical profiling of astronomical and space optics.  Bauer recently demonstrated an extremely successful optical aspheric profilometer under a NASA SBIR contract.  This nanometer-level profilometer could benefit greatly from this vastly increased dynamic range afforded by these new innovations.
Potential non-NASA applications: An instrument derived from the currently proposed project would be capable of measuring surface figure of large and small concave or convex aspheres with large aspheric departures, and would therefore be of great interest to much of the precision optics community.  One important application is extreme ultra violet or soft X-ray projection lithography, where absolute profiling of very smooth aspheres is critical.  Thus, this project would be of interest both to the commercial optics and semiconductor manufacturing communities.

Proposal Title: SiCf/SiC Composites w/ Variable Fiber Form for Monolithic SiC Optical Instrument
Small Business Concern_Address: Wilmington , MA01887 - 1020, SSG Precision Optronics, Inc
Principal Investigator_Name: In Phase II, the fabrication process will be optimized and an all SiC telescope using these techniques will be designed, modeled and fabricated.
Principal Investigator_Address: Jay Schwartz, SSG Precision Optronics, Inc
Technical Abstract: Silicon Carbide has been demonstrated as a high performance material for lightweighted optical systems because of it?s high specific stiffness and high thermal stability.  For passively athermal optical instrumentation, the metering structure can also be made of SiC, typically in the form of fiber reinforced ceramic matrix composites (CMCs).
Potential non-NASA applications: In Phase I, SSG will demonstrate a low-cost CMC material and fabrication process that combines the cost advantages and near-net-shape capabilities of our proprietary reaction bonded SiC with the fracture tough nature of traditional CMCs.  The focus in Phase I will be on developing techniques for incorporating various forms of SiC fiber (weave, long, short, chopped and whiskers) to provide design flexibility and different levels of fracture toughness and casting complexity.  Enabling these advanced CMCs is high temperature resistant SiC fibers and a novel interface layer comprised of nanocomposite boron-aluminum-nitrate (BAN) under development at the University of Illinois-Chicago and Drexel University.  This advanced interface layer will provide high temperature performance and a self-healing mechanism to prevent crack growth and degradation due to oxidation.

Proposal Title: Dynamics Optics Controls Structures (DOCS)
Technical Abstract: The proposed innovation is a system design suite that enables optimization of large, flexible opto-mechanical structures such as space-based observatories.  The suite is innovative because it combines validated design tools, or modules, for detailed system analysis with an automation layer that drives the analysis tools, permitting rapid evaluation of the trade space between many highly coupled design variables.  The analysis modules are general enough to be applicable for the complete program life cycle, from conceptual design to operational analysis, providing analysis traceability.  The automation layer handles the translation of high-level systems requirements into module-level design space constraints, and buffers the detailed analysis results.   The suite encompasses an archiving function, which enables the time evolution of the design to be explicitly tracked, facilitating the systems designer's understanding of the design space, and providing a formal means to manage risk.  The combination of detailed modeling accuracy with the automation necessary for trading a large design space provides analysis depth and breadth, leading to an optimal systems design.
Potential non-NASA applications: The first-tier customer for the DOCS suite is the deep space observatory community.  Potential commercial customers include Lockheed-Martin, TRW, and Ball Aerospace.  Second-tier customers are the earth-imaging community.  Potential customers include the NRO and AFRL.  Finally, Mide will attempt to identify a third-tier aerospace or industrial market, with the intent of finding a wider market to leverage the development effort of the design tools to a general purpose systems design and optimization suite.

Proposal Title: A Graded Density SiC Foam for Lightweight Optics
Technical Abstract: Lightweight silicon carbide optics and structures are extremely important to explore the Structure and Evolution of the Universe.  State-of-the-art SiC is too heavy, contains other phases which interfere with producing an acceptable optical surface and is anistropic causing distortions with temperature excursions.  In this program a functionally graded density isotropic silicon carbide foam will be formed insitu with a unique high density isotropic SiC structure which has a skin of defect free silicon carbide that can be polished ultra-smooth.  The functionally density graded isotropic SiC foam structure containing no other phases will be utilized to produce SiC optics with an areal density less than 1 kg/m2.  Sample optics will be delivered to NASA.
Potential non-NASA applications: The commercial potential in addition to lightweight optics for NASA are similar optics for defense systems and some commercial applications.  The density gradient SiC foam has a variety of commercial applications as high temperature insulation and structures.

Proposal Title: Micromachining Techniques to Enhance X-ray Microcalorimeter Array Fabrication
Principal Investigator_Name: The successful development of these microcalorimeter arrays into suitably functional detector systems that are commercially available would lead to a number of potential applications in industry in addition to the X-ray astronomy applications. The most promising of these is currently the use of microcalorimeter systems with Scanning Electron Microscopes. CSP Cryogenic Spectrometers GmbH and EDAX Inc. is one example of an industrial collaboration that have developed a high resolution energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer for microanalysis applications. While their systems are currently using other microcalorimeter array technologies, the successful development of magnetic microcalorimeters could make them the calorimeters of choice for this industry, and their cryogenic systems could relatively easily be adapted for operation with these devices. In addition there are a number of possible applications in non-invasive biomedical instruments such as those used for measuring magnetocardiograms and magnetoencephalograms, as well for non-destructive evaluation (NDE) for detection of corrosion and cracks in metals
Technical Abstract: ProcessTek describes an innovative large format cryogenic x-ray detector consisting of an array of magnetic microcalorimeters with SQUID readouts. Pixels consist of a thick-film x-ray absorber deposited on a paramagnetic alloy that is coupled to a dc SQUID. A research collaboration headed by Prof. Seidel at Brown University, including participants from the University of Heidelberg, Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory, Star Cryoelectronics and Hypres, have conducted a research program investigating the relevant properties of appropriate magnetic systems. They have achieved impressive results with individual pixel,microcalorimeter designs. Next, they will develop new microprocessing techniques and multiplexed SQUID electronics systems. Their Focal Plane Array design has significant fabrication problems to overcome to process a high performance and manufacturable array.
Potential non-NASA applications: The purpose of this proposed SBIR research plan is complementary to this effort. We propose to develop some specific practical processing details based on MEMS and micromachining techniques that will enable us to transform this high potential microcalorimeter concept, to a marketable product that could be sold to a potentially large market. We will work closely with Professor Seidel's collaboration, sharing ideas and investigation results, and members of this collaboration will test all new devices developed by ProcessTek at the appropriate cryogenic temperatures.

Proposal Title: Cosmic-ray Shower Detector Focal Plane
Small Business Concern_Address: 7 Deer Park Drive, Monmouth Junction , NJ   08852 - 1921
Principal Investigator_Address: 7 Deer Park Drive, Monmouth Junction , NJ08852 - 1921
Technical Abstract: The "Orbiting Wide-angle Light-collectors (OWL): Observing Cosmic Rays From Space" mission is one of the space obervatories in NASA's long range plan.  This proposal addresses the need for a detector array to match the several square meter focal plane of the envisaged OWL telescope, while maintaining high optical fill factor, low noise, and exposure times commensurate with the 3.3 us per km velocity and associated short optical pulse characteristics of the cosmic-ray induced fluorescence.  Phase I involves systems analysis and conceptual design of a "smart pixel" array tailored to detect and store these short optical pulses.  The cosmic ray shower image data is stored within the pixel for subsequent readout at a moderate data rate.  By incorporating discrimination, signal processing, and temporary storage within each pixel, the electronics associated with the cosmic ray shower focal plane can be greatly reduced in weight and power consumption.  Such smart-pixel arrays are applicable to both image tube and multi-channel photomultiplier tube readout.  In Phase II a prototype of the focal plane detector system would be built and evaluated.
Potential non-NASA applications: The primary commercial application is the OWL orbiting observatory and other international projects for cosmic ray research.  The smart pixel array technology will be invaluable in designing such CMOS arrays for other commercial applications requiring fast temporal response.

Proposal Title: Advanced Boundary Actuation for Improvement of Large Membrane Optical Figure
Technical Abstract: A family of lightweight, space qualified, zero-power-hold membrane pre-tension adjustment actuators is proposed.  These actuators would act on the membrane boundary in a quasistatic manner to update and trim out the membrane tension and shape following deployment and after major changes in on-orbit orientation or thermal environment.  They could also be used in a semi-active manner to adjust the tension and shift the resonant modes of the membrane to frequencies separated from the spectral content of narrowband disturbances.  For broadband disturbances, they would be used to prevent the transmission of energy from the supporting structure into the membrane itself or absorb it out of the membrane.  Another interesting application involves the ability to intentionally release portions of a membrane to reduce drag/inertia demands on attitude control systems after the majority of delta V has been extracted.  Three actuator concepts will be developed through component design, testing, and integration into large membrane structure models.  Piezoelectric and electromagnetic transducers will be incorporated.  Gossamer structures such as sun shields, solar sails, improved solar cell arrays, solar concentrators, radio wave antennas and collectors, all the way to science grade optical reflective flats and curved surfaces would benefit from the proposed innovation.
Potential non-NASA applications: The proposed actuators could be used across a wide range of potential NASA and DOD missions covering a variety of Space Science, Earth Science, and Aerospace Transportation Enterprise major efforts such as Origins (optics and sunshields for NGST, TPF, Life Finder, Planet Imager), Structure and Evolution of the Universe (ARISE), Sun-Earth-Connection and the Living with a Star Initiative (Solar Sails for Geostorm and North and South Pole Sitters), Exploration of the Universe (Solar Sails, SEP Concentrators and large communication antennas), the  Interstellar Probes and Precursor Missions, and ASTP (Concentrators for SOTV and Solar Sails) as well as the CETP own ULSOC and Gossamer Spacecraft Initiative efforts and other programs like technology development for Space Solar Power.  Potential terrestrial applications of the technology are also foreseen in large membrane building structure control and in the multi-billion dollar fiber optic routing industry.

Proposal Title: High Bandwidth, Large Dynamic-Range Sensor for Controllable Optics
Principal Investigator_Name: Creare's high bandwidth, large dynamic-range sensor is a non-contact position sensor that provides nanometer resolution with a dynamic range of greater than 100,000.  During Phase I we will demonstrate the feasibility of our approach.  During Phase II we will fabricate and deliver a prototype sensor.
Technical Abstract: The overall goal of this project is to design, fabricate, test, and deliver a high bandwidth, large dynamic-range sensor for controllable optical elements.  Active mirrors and other active optical elements are used in advanced imaging systems to improve overall performance of the imaging system.  For example, optical and infrared telescopes may employ active beam-steering mirrors and segmented primary optics.
Potential non-NASA applications: Active optics will be needed for next-generation, large telescopes to achieve diffraction-limited resolution.  To achieve proper active optical elements, a non-contact sensor is required that has a position measurement accuracy on the order of nanometers and it must be capable of large angular slews requiring total displacements on the order of 0.1 mm (or 100,000 nanometers).  Further, the sensor must have high bandwidth capability and operate at cryogenic temperatures.  These requirements necessitate the development of new metrology technologies to meet the demanding specifications.

Proposal Title: Throttleable Vacuum Arc Thruster for Precision Positioning
Small Business Concern_Address: 2235 Polvorosa Avenue, Suite 230, San Leandro , CA   94577 - 2249
Principal Investigator_Address: 2235 Polvorosa Avenue, Suite 230, San Leandro , CA94577 - 2249
Technical Abstract: Alameda Applied Sciences Corporation proposes to develop a new type of electric propulsion device dubbed the Throttleable Vacuum Arc Thruster (TVAT).  This thruster is itself a variant on an earlier thruster (the Vacuum Arc micro-Thruster (VA?-T)) that has been demonstrated via a recently concluded Phase I SBIR contract from BMDO (NASA/GRC contract NAS300129). The VA?T was verified to be a low mass (~100g) high efficiency (~13% measured), high Isp (1000-3000s) electric propulsion device. By combining the simple technology of an inductive energy storage circuit PPU with powerful electronics control, we will develop a thruster that can be remotely adjusted to deliver individual impulse bits from 0.25?Ns to 50?Ns with repetition rates varying from 1?1000 Hz while all the time providing an Isp of >1000s. The throttleable VAT proposed here is a pulsed device and hence can provide a wide range of impulse bits and a variety of repetition rates, which could satisfy coarse and ultra-fine control demands integrated in the same simple system. This thruster will be well suited to provide precision control for spacecraft constellations including optical interferometry, while offering low mass (<300g including the PPU), simplicity (no moving parts), high efficiency (?15%) and low cost of manufacturing.
Potential non-NASA applications: The primary application of the specific electric propulsion thruster to be developed in the proposed work will be for the StarLight Optical Interferometry mission. However, beyond this immediate application, the thruster could find use for larger or smaller spacecraft, with further development.

Proposal Title: Capillarity Driven Flow Of Propellant Liquids In Colloidal Satellite Thrusters
Technical Abstract: Research is proposed on the evaluation and development of a novel Electrospray "Wick-Injector" for supplying liquid to colloidal satellite thrusters using electrostatic fields to produce and accelerate micro charged droplets of non-volatile fluids. Depending solely on capillarity driven flow, as in the wick of a candle, the injector requires no mechanical pumps or pressurizing gas, is very light, energy efficient, and structurally simple. Liquid is delivered only as rapidly as the field can disperse it, so that the flow rate depends entirely on the dimensions of the wick, the properties of the liquid, and the applied voltage. The flow is inherently self-sustaining at a rate immune to plugging or disturbance by dirt particles, and is easily varied by adjustment of the applied voltage. The thruster readily lends itself to multiplexing and can thus provide thrust levels over a wide range and direction. Effects of radiation on colloidal fluids used with the proposed thruster will also be studied.
Potential non-NASA applications: Commercial applications include a portable air contaminant dosimeter for air quality and chemical agent detection, an improved source for electrospray mass spectrometry, and a colloidal thruster for commercial satellites.

Proposal Title: Optimal Path Planning for Formation Flying Applications with Collision Avoidance
Small Business Concern_Address: 500 West Cummings Park, Suite 3000, Woburn , MA   01801 - 6580
Principal Investigator_Address: 500 West Cummings Park, Suite 3000, Woburn , MA01801 - 6580
Technical Abstract: In this project, we will develop and test strategies for optimal path planning for formation flying applications under collision avoidance constraints. The overall approach will be primarily applied to the U-V mapping problem, but can be extended to a number of distributed spacecraft interferometry control problems. Phase I will focus on evaluating the feasibility of solving the optimal path planning problem using techniques based on Differential Flatness, Linear Matrix Inequalities (LMI), and optimization tools for nonconvex constraints. Specific tasks include: (i) Development of simplified test cases; (ii) Development of trajectory generation algorithms; (iii) Test and tuning of the algorithms on candidate test cases; (iv) Development of plans for Phase II; and (v) Reports and Meetings. Phase II will involve (a) the extension of the proposed approach to other formation flying interferometry problems, (b) the development of a commercially viable toolbox for trajectory generation with collision avoidance constraints, and (c) the application to future multi-spacecraft missions. The development of the above core technologies will serve as a foundation for Phase III commercialization.
Potential non-NASA applications: The commercial applications of this technology are enormous and exist in areas such as control of automated air traffic management systems, automated vehicle highway systems, chemical process control, power generation and distribution, C3I, manufacturing systems and computer-communication networks including Internet. NASA Space Science (ST3, ST5, TPF) and Earth Science Enterprises (EOS, NMP, ESTP) will directly benefit from this technology.

Proposal Title: A Magnetic Refrigerator for Cooling at 2 K
Small Business Concern_Address: 1367 Camino Robles Way, San Jose , CA95120 - 4925
Principal Investigator_Name: ? Superconducting magnets for power generation and energy storage
Principal Investigator_Address: ? Low temperature superconducting electronics., Ali Kashani
Technical Abstract: An Adiabatic Demagnetization Refrigerator (ADR) will be developed to operate between 2 K and 10 K and provide 0.1 W of cooling at 2 K. The ADR can be used as a pre-cooler for a Dilution Refrigerator (DR) or a low-temperature ADR stage. Alternatively it can be integrated into a He II storage dewar to eliminate cryogen boil-off. The magnetic material selected for operating in this temperature range is Gadolinium Gallium Garnet (GGG). During the magnetic cycling it is necessary to connect or isolate the GGG to/from the 2 K heat source and the 10 K heat sink. This is accomplished by employing components with no moving parts thereby increasing reliability. At 2 K this will be accomplished by means of a 3He heat pipe. The innovative design of the heat pipe minimizes the amount of liquid required in its operation for a fast turn-off time. At 10 K, a 4He gas-gap heat switch will be employed. The efficiency of the refrigeration cycle is greatly affected by the performances of the heat switches. In the design the on and off conductances and the switching times of the heat switches will be optimized to achieve a high cycle efficiency.
Potential non-NASA applications: The proposed ADR can be employed for re-liquefying helium in several commercial applications, such as:

Proposal Title: High Pressure Micro-Sampling System for In Situ Deep Subsurface Measurements
Small Business Concern_Address: 5552 Cathedral Oaks Road, Santa Barbara , CA   93111 - 1406
Principal Investigator_Address: 5552 Cathedral Oaks Road, Santa Barbara , CA93111 - 1406
Technical Abstract: Thorleaf Research, Inc. proposes to develop a miniature, aseptic, high pressure micro-sampling system for in situ measurements in deep subsurface environments. This addresses a key technology gap for astrobiology related studies, mainly how to acquire and process samples for in situ analysis while meeting challenging mass, volume and power constraints.  In high pressure deep subsurface environments this becomes especially important, since the integrity of the sample may be compromised by degassing of volatile components if brought to the surface. Our proposed high pressure micro-sampling inlet system addresses this by collecting a micro-sample in the high pressure environment, then transferring it into a protected low pressure environment for processing and in situ analysis.  This enabling technology will allow in situ analysis by spectroscopic measurements, GC/MS, or other techniques that inherently require low pressures for operation. The goal of our proposed SBIR Phase I effort is to demonstrate feasibility for a high pressure micro-sampling system for deep subsurface in situ measurement applications of interest to NASA, and to develop a detailed design for fabricating prototype instrumentation in Phase II.
Potential non-NASA applications: Commercial application of the proposed high pressure micro-sampling system for in situ measurements in deep subsurface environments will address needs for scientific research instrumentation, energy exploration and environmental monitoring.  Analysis of commercial instrumentation markets shows that two of the three major growth areas for analytical instrumentation are real-time analysis and environmental monitoring, with projected annual growth rates of more than 15%.  There is a significant technology gap for low power instrumentation that can be miniaturized for field use.  The proposed SBIR effort to develop a miniaturized, high pressure micro-sampling system for in situ measurements in deep subsurface environments addresses this need in an innovative way, and thus technical developments in the proposed program could have a significant market impact.

Proposal Title: Novel Method of Subsurface Water Detection
Small Business Concern_Firm: Subsurface water search remains an important problem in less developed areas.  A compact REWARD can save the cost of unnecessary drilling.  Small water pocket in various non-metalic structures can be detected using this method.
Principal Investigator_Name: - Ability to detect the presence of water in relatively small enclosures with no defined interface
Principal Investigator_Address: In addition, the REsonance WAter Radar Detector (REWARD) will be capable of remote surface mapping and possibly of detecting some organic and inorganic water solutes., Phase I research will prove both experimentally and theoretically the feasibility of the novel method and will lead to the REWARD prototype design to be built in Phase II.
Technical Abstract: WaveBand Corporation proposes a novel method for subsurface water detection, appropriate for planetary exploration.  It makes use of millimeter-wave/microwave radar.  However, in contrast to the current ground penetrating radar approach that relies on the detection of ice (permafrost), or solid-crust/water, interface due to the difference in their dielectric constants, WaveBand?s system is based on the detection of water-specific resonances in the millimeter wave range of the frequency spectrum.  The specific innovations are:
Potential non-NASA applications: - Elimination of the water interface factor from the detection method.  That factor is the main source of uncertainties due to unknown interface geometry and the dielectric constants of the surface(s)

Proposal Title: A miniature underwater vehicle/benthic lander for through-ice deployment
Technical Abstract: In astrobiology research, it is useful to study benthic microbial ecosystems found under the ice in Earth's polar regions, which give us valuable insights for detecting extant life or evidence of past life in what may have been similar settings on Mars and Europa. These environments are logistically remote, and the barrier of thick ice prevents easy access. Most benthic studies require creating large open holes to give divers access to the water, which are time consuming and laborious, and, in the case of glacier-covered lakes, make it impossible to maintain aseptic conditions. We propose to develop a miniaturized remotely operated vehicle (ROV)/benthic lander system that can pass vertically through a 25cm hole (a standard portable drill size) and is operated through a cable from the surface, thereby simplifying access and reducing hazardous human exposure. The ROV can deposit the lander for long-term in situ measurements, and return later to recover it, increasing the range, depth, and duration of these studies. This system will also be used to evaluate concepts for Europa exploration, including deployment of instrument arrays and imaging systems, and modes of aseptic operation. In Phase II, a prototype system will be constructed and tested in suitable field locations.
Potential non-NASA applications: Even the smallest commercial off-the-shelf ROVs generally have too large a footprint to be of use in many applications where the only access is through a small opening. The miniaturized ROV and instrumentation package to be developed in this proposal have commercial applications wherever size and/or portability are constraints. Potential applications include inspection and sampling in hazardous environments with restricted access, such as enclosed potable water storage tanks and reservoirs, ship ballast and bilge tanks, power generation coolant pumps and pipework, and oil production storage cells. In the scientific community, this technology has applications for data collection, sediment sampling, and environmental monitoring. This small lightweight system will be highly portable, and can be more easily transported into remote environments that were previously out of reach for scientific research and exploration. Vertically-oriented vehicles such as the one proposed in this study are especially suitable for applications with thermally-generated vertical currents, such as around thermal vents and in nuclear reactor vessels. Deep Ocean Engineering, Inc. (DOEI) has a proven record of successfully commercializing technology funded through SBIR grants. SBIR-funded developments frequently are integrated into DOEI's extensive line of underwater products and sold worldwide through its international network of sales representatives.

Proposal Title: Low-Noise High-Resolution Multiplexer Electronics for Deformable Mirrors
Technical Abstract: Imaging of extrasolar planets requires a high-channel count deformable mirror to correct for system aberrations thereby narrowing the point-spread function.  The mirror would be used in experiments such as coronographs that would obscure the bright star while enhancing imaging around the star.  Requirements for such a system demand extremely fine control of the surface of the deformable mirror.  While the mirrors built by Xinetics have been shown to be controllable to angstrom resolution, the electronics needed for such a system must be refined.  Xinetics multiplexer electronics allow for mirror control in an extremely compact package.  The next step is to develop electronics that allow the experimenter to take advantage of the ultra-fine resolution capabilities of the mirrors.  This proposal outlines the steps needed to increase the resolution and decrease the noise where resolution would approach 0.1 Angstroms.
Potential non-NASA applications: Low-Noise multiplexer electronics have applications in a variety of low-speed adaptive optics applications.  Currently applications such as opthalmic imaging, laser correction, and satellite imaging would all benefit from this technology.

Proposal Title: High Density Active Deformable Mirrors by Micromachining
Technical Abstract: In Phase I of the SBIR program LEEOAT Company will develop and optimize the design and the fabrication process of a high-resolution and cost-effective active deformable mirror (ADM) for space high-contrast astrophysical imaging applications.  The innovative ADM device architecture will be based on LEEOAT Company's unique laser ultraprecision micromachining technology in exotic materials. The effort will also include the theoretical modeling of the ADM performance.  On the basis of the theoretical results, the ADM architecture will be optimized.  LEEOAT Company will reduce the innovation to practice and conduct experiments to verify its expected performance.  Finally, LEEOAT Company will estimate the cost/effort for the fabrication and testing of the ADM system to be performed in Phase II of the program.
Potential non-NASA applications: The development of the cost-effective high-performance active deformable mirror will open a large window of opportunity for space, commercial and military applications.  Estimate commercial market can exceed 2M per annum.

Proposal Title: A Revolution in Electron Spectrometers for Biosignature Detection in Minerals
Technical Abstract: Studies of minerals and meteorites using x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) have demonstrated the sensitivity of XPS and its ability to deliver both qualitative and quantitative information on the chemical state of detected elements. In recent experiments using an imaging spectromicroscopy system at the Aladdin storage ring, sub-micron images of embedded organic structures in mineral specimens have been resolved. This combination of chemical specificity with spatial resolution offers a major advance in the search for residual biomarkers. Until recently there were no feasible ways to develop a plausible planetary version of either an XPS or photoelectron microscopy system. Surface/Interface Inc. proposes the key technology development needed to realize a miniaturized photoelectron spectrometer with potentially sub-micron spatial resolution. This spectrometer would be based on a unique development in charged particle energy analyzers that exhibit a very high multiplex advantage proposed by Dr. M. Kelly at Stanford. This proposal would enable an, in-situ, XPS systems with a 2500 fold reduction in volume, power and mass as compared to laboratory systems. This 1.5 to 5 kg instrument will revolutionize in-situ chemical analysis of solid surface and subsurface samples with unique sensitivity for organic compounds and a wide range of applicability to OSS programs.
Potential non-NASA applications: The increased detector efficiency of the proposed electron energy spectrometer (MRS) will have a major impact in electron spectroscopy applications.  The major commercial techniques are X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) and Auger Electron Spectroscopy (AES).  In order of market size, the biggest effect of the new technology will be in the use of AES for Defect Review for particles less then 100nm dimensions in the semiconductor industry.  This market is rapidly approaching $1B per year.  The ability to replace the x-ray detectors (EDX) in use to day will lower the size of particles that can be analyzed.  Applied Materials, Sunnyvale, CA, was able to a different improvement and gained 60% of the market in 2 years (International Technology Roadmap for Semiconductors).  Another market will be the extension of XPS to spatial resolutions in the 1 micron range.  Now this is done at synchrotrons, which limit the use of the tools, especially where turn around time is important.  The size of this market is not clear.  The next direction will be to concentrate on much smaller XPS and AES instruments that can be used in production environments.  Here the efficiency will lower the cost and size to open up new applications.

Proposal Title: Self-Calibrating Vector Magnetometer
Technical Abstract: This 2001 NASA SBIR Phase I proposal is in response to subtopic S4.01 for Science Instruments for Conducting Solar System Exploration. This proposal describes the design of an innovative high accuracy Self-Calibrating Vector Magnetometer (SVM) for space science applications. The SVM will offer significant improvements over the state of the art in terms of size, mass, power, and accuracy. The proposed laser-pumped helium magnetometer will allow miniaturization of the helium cell sensing element, provide accurate measurements of the orthogonal vector components of the magnetic field, and incorporate a high accuracy scalar field measurement mode for in situ calibration of the instrument. The SVM will utilize fiber-optic technology to deliver and receive the laser-pumping radiation, which will allow remote location of the electronics from the boom-mounted sensing element. The helium cell sensing element will operate over a wide temperature range and will be resistant to the destructive effects of intense radiation from solar flares and energetic trapped particles in planetary magnetospheres. The SVM will have commercial, military, and space applications, and will be an important science instrument for conducting Solar System exploration.
Potential non-NASA applications: The Self-Calibrating Vector Magnetometer (SVM) will have a variety of commercial applications. The instrument could be used for space-borne measurements of Earth's magnetic field which would support telecommunication applications and climate predictions. The SVM could be used for geophysical airborne and surface exploration, and could be used in geomagnetic observatories. The SVM could find use for intrusion detection, vehicle surveillance and shop-lifting prevention security systems. The capabilities of the SVM, with its absolute accuracy, greatly improved sensitivity, omni-directionality, and high frequency detection could open up new applications for portable magnetometers and general magnetics use.

Proposal Title: Detecting Fossilized Microscopic Life Forms on Mars with Dual-Energy CT
Technical Abstract: This purpose of this SBIR Phase 1 project is to select and test the basic elements of a dual-energy, computed tomography imaging system that will travel to Mars and examine small rocks and minerals for evidence of fossilized life. The goal is to achieve three-dimensional volume images with 10-micron spatial resolution in the reconstructed image and to provide identification at that resolution, of both the density and the effective atomic number of the material being examined.  The focus of phase I will be to determine the dual-energy formalism and to understand the best combination of detector and radiation source to provide a useful imaging system.
Potential non-NASA applications: The proposed effort is significant, not only for space exploration but also for earth-based micro-tomography applications. Microfocus CT is needed for better inspection of printed circuit boards and microelectronic components.  Other applications are in military and civilian non-destructive testing, mineralogy, paleontology, composites, forensics, small-animal scanning, etc.  In several of these, dual energy can improve visibility of constituents that are not readily distinguishable by density.  These include fossils in rock matrix, fibers in two-component composites, and small concentrations of metal-tagged drugs in mice in pharmaceutical research.

Proposal Title: Nanofabricated GC
Principal Investigator_Name: ? Low cost, in-situ, monitoring of pollutants in air, water and soil

Technical Abstract: A nanofabricated, palm-sized gas chromatography (GC) is proposed for the fast,  in-situ, analysis of chemicals in space.  A prototype miniature GC column-oven subsystem will be designed, nanofabricated and tested in this Phase I to prove the technical feasibility.
Potential non-NASA applications: The proposed innovation will readily fit the following applications if proved successful:

Proposal Title: Autonomous Mars Airplane Navigation (AMAN)
Principal Investigator_Name: These applications are highly cost constrained due to the commercial nature of the products. This leads to a constraint on the available processing capability designed into the system. The same multi-resolution techniques and use of regions of interest for focused processing are required to enable these applications. The techniques developed under this SBIR provide an enabling capability for these applications. Moreover, PercepTek has existing relationships with commercial product suppliers that can be tapped to enable rapid technology transfer during phase II.
Technical Abstract: Many of the most scientifically interesting areas on Mars, such as Layered sedimentary rock and recent aeolian and groundwater processes, cannot be adequately studied using remotely sensed data and cannot be accessed by Landers. Autonomous airplanes promise to provide accessibility to these areas. However, current Mars airplane concepts suffer from two fundamental limitations that impact the scientific value of the missions. First, mission duration is limited by the severe mass constraints of an airplane and the impact of diurnal cycle on available power. Proposed mission durations range from tens of minutes to a few hours. Second, communication contact times for relay orbiters will be short (on the order of 20 minutes) thereby limiting data return. These constraints create an operational requirement for precision autonomous navigation (10 meter accuracy) enabling acquisition of highly focused scientific data. This research program will demonstrate the feasibility of using Landmark recognition to achieve autonomous navigation with accuracies better than 10 meters. Unique multi-resolution algorithms enable operations within the throughput limitations of existing flight processors. MGS data will be used in phase I to demonstrate the ability to recognize geodetically referenced features. During phase II an flight test will be conducted on an existing flight testbed.
Potential non-NASA applications: Many commercial applications for vision-based control have been identified and include:Autonomous lane departure warning systems for long haul truckers; Eventual automation of long haul operations; Collision warning systems; Autonomous agriculture systems (plowing, planting, and harvesting); and Automated mobile security systems

Proposal Title: A Versatile Apparatus and Method for Remote Autonomous Robot Mobility
Technical Abstract: Robotics intended for exploration of extremely remote and harsh environments must be extraordinarily versatile as well as robust. They must be able to perform in and adapt to unknown and potentially variable physical surroundings. Robots with tracks, wheels or articulating legs have provided effective mobility on certain kinds of terrain. However, these same robots would likely fail if their mission's operational requirement included roving over roughly contoured surfaces or in media such as water, sand, slush, or ice that may be found on Mars or Europa. We will investigate a novel method for autonomous robotic locomotion over land, through water and loose sediments, and even through snow and ice. Our focus will be on the mobility methodologies derived from selected biological examples, primarily snake and worm morphologies. These creatures have evolved versatile techniques for mobility that may translate well for robotics operating in unknown workspaces. We shall examine existing research and evaluate its feasibility for our intended applications. We also will draw on our own experience and expertise of designing and building over 450 remotely operated vehicles and manned submersibles to guide us to workable designs to be investigated in Phase II.
Potential non-NASA applications: An autonomous robot with snake- and/or worm-like mobility has broad commercialization potential. Most robot mobility platforms are confined to a specific relatively homogeneous workspace. Worm and snake robots would possess unprecedented operational versatility, having the ability to adapt to changing conditions and component failures, facilitating seamless negotiation of many environments including land, water, and loose sediment. A natural opportunity for commercialization will be internal pipe inspection, using its capacity to easily navigate complex shapes. A vehicle of this design could perform hazardous waste site inspections and provide in situ analytical sampling and testing. Military applications include surreptitious at-sea deployment, for example, from a submarine, transiting through open water, moving inland via rivers or sewer pipes, and onto shore and then overland, even up stairs if desired. Autonomous deployment of electronic sensors or ordinance packages would be possible. The vehicle could swim to a pre-programmed site, bury itself and remain on station for extended periods either collecting data or awaiting further instructions. Like a silkworm, this kind of vehicle could spool out a real-time communications link in the form of an optical fiber.

Proposal Title: Plasma Lysis Decontamination System with Mass Spectrometric Detection
Technical Abstract: Napneumatics, Inc. has recently developed an atmospheric pressure, low temperature plasma lysis unit that can highly efficiently and universally deactivate biological materials including vegetative cells, spores, toxins, and viruses on surfaces. The plasma lysis approach presented in this proposal offers a number of advantages over other state-of-the-art techniques, including: (1) extremely high decontamination efficiency, (2) very short decontamination times of in the order of 10 seconds or less, (3) high versatility and ability to control the process due to low system inertia and the use of electric fields, (4) produces no waste heat or materials, (5) can be easily integrated into a complete decontamination and detection system, and (6) enhances the performance of the downstream detection systems.  The goal of this project is to evaluate the feasibility of miniaturization of this technique for the development of a hand-held unit that simultaneously decontaminates a surface by plasma treatment and identifies the biological contaminants while archiving data.  This plasma lysis unit extracts the intracellular components of biological materials on a surface to facilitate identification by mass spectrometry.  After plasma treatment for 60 seconds or less, a micromachined virtual impactor collector (MicroVIC) extracts the particles from the surface and deposits onto a one-millimeter spot on a tape (for archiving).  These biological materials on the spot are softly ionized by means of a matrix assisted laser desorption ionization (MALDI) technique and the particles are identified by a miniature time-of-flight mass spectrometer. Concurrently, the vaporized cellular components from the surface biological materials are adsorbed for mass spectrometry analysis.   Both the biological particulate spectra and vapor breakdown products allow a complete picture of the biological material to be formed from terrestrial or possibly extraterrestrial material.
Potential non-NASA applications: The target application areas for the final product, hand-held plasma lysis decontamination unit will be for the first responders for biological threat, food processor communities for bio-contamination, and the military for anti-terrorism campaigns.  We believe these three markets are of significant size and would readily embrace the decontamination system proposed for development.

Proposal Title: A Novel MEMS for Rapid Biocontamination Assessment on Flight Hardware
Technical Abstract: The need to protect Earth from extra-terrestrial contamination, and vice versa, is a growing concern as space flight missions extend into unfamiliar planetary atmospheres.  Whereas the transport of biological contamination during space flight missions could pose extreme global threats, reliable sterilization and subsequent validation procedures need to be developed.  The proposed technology aims to provide a reliable, real-time sampling and analysis device for the assessment of biocontamination levels on space flight hardware.  Hydrodynamic removal of biological contaminants from a surface will be achieved using a microfluidic device that will electrokinetically deliver the sampled material to a reaction reservoir.  On-chip electroporation will be utilized to release the genetic material, followed by the selective amplification of mRNA from viable organisms.  Hybridization of the amplified genetic material to nucleic acid modified electrodes will generate an electrochemical current that will indicate the presence of specific biological contaminants.  In essence, this novel microelectromechanical system (MEMS) will perform automated sampling, selective target amplification, and electrochemical analysis in order to provide rapid, quantitative information regarding the presence of biocontamination on flight hardware.   In the Phase I, the feasibility of this innovation to efficiently "sample" surfaces for biological contamination will be demonstrated.
Potential non-NASA applications: The proposed device for surface biocontamination assessment has far-reaching benefits for space flight as an effective method to ensure the protection of Earth from extraterrestrial microorganisms, as well as safeguard other planetary environments from terrestrial harm.  In addition, the complete automation of the device makes it ideal for standalone monitoring of sterile work areas such as hospitals, biological laboratories, and semiconductor fabrication facilities.

Proposal Title: Smart Thin Film NiTi Based Membranes for Space Based Deployables
Technical Abstract: The current move towards launching smaller lower cost space mission payloads requires among other things, development of thin film structures to deploy multifunctional structures.  Shape memory alloy (SMA) thin films on low density polymeric materials for deployable large space antenna applications have recently garnered considerable attention as potential solutions.  These large flexible structures (40m) are fabricated with lightweight compliant systems, (e.g. thin films) to permit deployment.  Low internal pressure provides much of the structure?s ability to deploy, sustain loads and retain a desired geometrical configuration within specified limits of accuracy.  However, precise control of the antenna?s shape would demand a distributed actuation and control scheme.  A distributed compact actuation scheme could allow the structure to adapt to changing environments or mission needs.  Recent developments in the deposition of thin film shape memory materials, in particular NiTi thin films, suggest that shape memory materials are the best choice for large deployable space antennas.
Potential non-NASA applications: Commercial applications for a thin film SMA can be numerous.  The possibility of incorporating the material as a solid state actuator in MEMS devices have yet to be fully explored.  Biomedical applications for NiTi SMA have just started taking off with the recent success of NiTi stents.  NiTi as a cavitation protection material have been proven in research, but commercially incorporating the technology have been hindered by a lack of a film deposition technique.

Proposal Title: Space Rigidizable, Deployable Ultra-Lightweight Microcellular CHEM Foams
Technical Abstract: Space rigidizable and deployable structures with ultra-lightweight, high rigidity, space durability, and high impact resistance are desirable to improve the reliability and affordability of space structures. Some of the components currently in use like shelter or space station use double-wall thick films with high internal pressure.  All these hollow components are vulnerable in space because of many debris and meteorites that can strike them.  They will lose their functions if hit and damaged by foreign objects. We propose to fill the cavities of these hollow components by an ultra-lightweight CHEM foam that can rigidize the space structure in space so that they can maintain their functions even they are struck by debris.  Foams processed by the conventional chemical-blowing agent have toxicity problems.  In this phase I research, we propose to process ultra-lightweight microcellular foams from CHEM and/or other shape memory polymers using an environmental friendly technique.  Our microcellular CHEM foams will have higher mechanical properties than those processed by the conventional techniques.  The shape memory foam can be packed into a very small volume and recovers its shape and rigidizes in space, thereby considerably reduce the launching cost yet provide high rigidity for space structures.
Potential non-NASA applications: The proposed ultra-lightweight microcellular foams from CHEM and other shape memory polymers have a number of potential applications for space structures including rigidified boom and support structures for Gossamer space structures, rover subsystems like wheels, chasis, insulation box, masts,  solar array deployment device, shelters and hangars for space habitats, airlocks, electronics box, tanks/shells/shields, solar array, radar boards, support structures for telecommunication subsystems like struts and beams, etc.. Shape memory gels have been explored to perform various functions including artificial muscles and organs, drug-delivery devices, chemical valves, and actuators.

Proposal Title: Electrochromic Thermal Stabilization of Large Deployable Structures
Small Business Concern_Address: Tampa , FL33710 - 9998, Eclipse Energy Systems, Inc.
Principal Investigator_Name: In Phase II of this effort, samples of the electrochromic devices will be tested to determine their tolerance to high vacuum, UV light, and bombardment with energetic oxygen ions. The design will be optimized to improve performance, reliability, and durability in the space environment.
Principal Investigator_Address: Nick Kislov, Eclipse Energy Systems, Inc.
Technical Abstract: Significant modulation of solar reflectance, solar absorption, and IR emissivity can be achieved with electrochromic devices operating at very low voltages. They use very little energy and can maintain their state of solar reflectance, solar absorption, and IR emissivity for some time after the potential has been removed. Devices fabricated as a monolithic stack of solid state inorganic materials can withstand the harsh space environment. These kinds of Variable Electrochromic Membranes(VEMs), with no moving parts, are well suited for active thermal control of spacecraft and deployable aerospace membrane structures.
Potential non-NASA applications: The Phase I effort will produce 100cm2 VEMs on ultra-thin polymer substrates with an areal density of 7g/M2 or less, modulations of emittance from 0.1 to 0.5, and solar absorptance from 0.2 to 0.8. The optical, thermal, and electrical performance of these devices will be thoroughly characterized. Detailed calculations will be performed to predict the thermal performance of these electrochromic coatings.

Proposal Title: Low Power High Speed Digital Signal Isolator
Small Business Concern_Address: 11409 Valley View Road, Eden Prairie , MN   55344 - 3617
Principal Investigator_Address: 11409 Valley View Road, Eden Prairie , MN55344 - 3617
Technical Abstract: This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will demonstrate highly sensitive linear spin-valve sensors with optimized bias points, and will also demonstrate the feasibility of their application in digital isolator devices.   The linear spin-valve sensors with  high sensitivity will be designed and fabricated by manipulating the anisotropies involved in the free layer, e.g.  the uniaxial anisotropy and  the shape anisotropy.   In order to reduce the hysteresis due to both the multi-domain formation in the free layer and the detrimental effect of the fringe fields from the pinned layer, the free layer will be biased by direct coupling with an antiferromagnetic (AF) layer, and the pinned layer will be replaced by a pinned synthetic antiferromagnetic sandwich (CoFe/Ru/CoFe).   In addition to the design, materials selection and process control will be used to optimize the sensor performance.  The ultimate goal in this program is to fabricate and demonstrate low power high speed digital isolator devices using linear spin-valve sensors developed in Phase I. The current NVE digital isolator process will be modified for the proposed low power high speed digital isolator.  The success of this Phase I project will provide a solid framework for the Phase II to build high speed, radiation-hard digital isolator devices. One of our strategies in Phase II is to combine the NVE magnetic isolator technology  with the current existing radiation-hard IC processes (as announced by Honeywell, Peregrine Semiconductor and Lockheed Martin) to develop and fabricate miniature radiation-hard digital signal isolators.
Potential non-NASA applications: The high sensitive linear spin-valve sensors developed in this research have immediate application in NVE's isolator technology, which will   lead to low power high speed signal isolator products suitable  for both military and commercial applications.   In addition, the linear spin-valve materials can also be used in field sensors and read head devices.

Proposal Title: An Innovative Architecture for Deep Space RF Communication
Technical Abstract: We propose a new ultra-compact system for constructing X- and Ka- band communications systems, greatly reducing size and weight.  We further propose a new architecture within this system to allow high transmit power from a fully characterized and reliable solid state source.
Potential non-NASA applications: Mobile wireless applications have similar requirements to aerospace communications.  Compact, low weight, high data rate components are required for mobile broadband communications, including in particular broadband unlicensed wireless LANs at 5 and 60 GHz.

Proposal Title: Compact High-Efficiency Ka-Band RF Amplifier
Technical Abstract: This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will involve the experimental investigation of a compact high-efficiency Ka-band rf amplifier (CRFA) for rf communications applications in exploration of the solar system.  The CRFA is a compact vacuum tube that uses a simple, lightweight two-cavity system to efficiently produce high-frequency rf radiation with very high-efficiency, making the CRFA ideal for space applications.  The device is based on novel synchronous interactions between a small-diameter electron beam and high-frequency rotating wave fields.  Phase I is aimed at initial theoretical and numerical study of the CRFA, as well as particle-in-cell computer studies to establish credible estimates of output power, efficiency, gain and other key parameters.  Once fully developed, the CRFA should be capable of replacing conventional traveling-wave tubes in telecommunication systems for future space missions by offering substantial improvements in size, weight, and especially efficiency over its counterparts.
Potential non-NASA applications: This compact source should be able to efficiently produce hundreds of watts of electromagnetic radiation in the 32 GHz regime with electronic efficiency as high as 50%.  If successful, this rf source will efficiently provide coherent high average-power millimeter-wave radiation for many civilian and military applications that require high-frequency electromagnetic radiation.

Proposal Title: Surface Enhanced Silicon Avalanche Photodiodes for Near-IR Detection
Small Business Concern_Address: Radiation Monitoring Devices, Inc., 44 Hunt Street
Principal Investigator_Name: The proposed technology will have numerous important commercial applications, such as imaging altimeters, LIDAR systems, near-IR spectroscopy, free-space optical communication, optical mammography and tomography, tissue oxygenation studies and many other applications.  A successful program could potentially revolutionize any field that is presently limit by the lack of sensitive detection at 1064 nm, where robust and compact transmission technology is readily available.
Principal Investigator_Address: Radiation Monitoring Devices, Inc., 44 Hunt Street
Technical Abstract: This Phase I SBIR describes a new approach to enhancing the sensitivity at 1064 nm of high gain avalanche photodiodes (APDs), developed at Radiation Monitoring Devices (RMD).  The process utilizes an innovative technique to microtexture the front surface of the APD using high power, ultra-short laser pulses (100 femto-seconds). The laser processed silicon surface exhibits remarkably high absorption characteristics over a large range of wavelengths (0.4 - 3 mm).  In addition, specular reflectance and transmittance are extremely low for wavelengths up to 12 mm. Evidence of silicon bandgap transformations makes this remarkable absorptance extremely promising for present detector technology needs.
Potential non-NASA applications: The ultimate goal of this project is to use laser microtexturing technology to develop a high speed, high gain, low noise APD array sensor module with significantly improved near-infrared (IR) response.  The APD array sensor will be an extremely valuable tool for long distance communication and LIDAR/LADAR applications.

Proposal Title: Clustered Vacuum Arc Thruster for Deep Space Missions
Small Business Concern_Address: 2235 Polvorosa Avenue, Suite 230, San Leandro , CA   94577 - 2249
Principal Investigator_Address: 2235 Polvorosa Avenue, Suite 230, San Leandro , CA94577 - 2249
Technical Abstract: Alameda Applied Sciences Corporation proposes to develop a new Clustered Vacuum Arc Thruster (CVAT) as an electric propulsion micro-thruster for microspacecraft with mass <=40kg with available thruster power ~40W. For deep space missions, high Isp thrusters are needed to minimize on board propellant mass. For electric thrusters such as the Pulsed Plasma Thruster and the Vacuum Arc Thruster, a challenge is feed of the propellant during long missions requiring >kg of total propellant. If the feed mechanism involves moving parts, its reliability is an issue, especially with active control. An innovative solution to this problem is proposed: deploy an array of individual, static thrusters, each of which delivers ~10g of total eroded propellant. An array of 100 such devices would then deliver a kg of propellant, with no moving parts. The innovation is the use of miniature solid-state switches in our inductive PPU driver that enable programmable switching of the drive power pulses from one thruster to another. By so doing, one effectively switches power out of a given cathode once it has completed its useful mission life. Such a Clustered Vacuum Arc Thruster array (CVAT) has no moving parts and yet delivers ~1kg propellant loads for various nanosatellite missions.
Potential non-NASA applications: The primary application of the specific electric propulsion thruster to be developed in the proposed work will be for small spacecraft ~10 kg. However, beyond this immediate application, the thruster could find use for larger or smaller spacecraft, with further development.

Proposal Title: Deep Space Power and Propulsion Systems
Technical Abstract: Solar arrays are the preferred technology for spacecraft power generation, but the high solar flux and high temperature environment of near-sun inner planetary missions, and the low solar flux, low temperature environment of far-sun outer planetary missions pose severe problems for their operation. Some gravity assist missions need their solar array to operate at earth distance, near-sun and far-sun conditions, as well as planetary orbits which pose their own thermal problems due to planetary radiation and albedo. This SBIR investigates a concentrator design that has high concentration ratio to allow reasonable fluxes onto the solar cell when far from the sun, limits flux onto the solar cell when the solar array is near the sun. In addition, the design limits the thermal absorption of planetary albedo, and limits thermal rejection when far from the sun to prevent excessively cold operating temperatures. The Deep Space Concentrator design is based on a one-axis, parabolic trough reflector with a separate radiator, and uses a unique solar cell receiver aperture limitation, and a thermostat radiator to allowing operation in a wide variety of solar illumination and thermal flux environments.
Potential non-NASA applications: Solar concentrators have commercial space and terrestrial applications because of the ability to replace expensive solar cells with inexpensive reflectors. High concentration ratios (CR) provide the best economic performance, since the solar cell material per watt is significantly reduced, but optical and thermal management techniques and their associated components are critical design features. This work advances the state-of-the-art of these critical design features, and could allow very high CR designs to be implemented, enabling the use of the most expensive, most efficient solar cells, and thereby decreasing balance-of-system costs associated with energy collection and conversion.

Proposal Title: Nanoscale Cathode Materials for High Capacity Li Ion Batteries
Small Business Concern_Address: 20 New England Business Center, Andover , MA   01810 - 1077
Principal Investigator_Address: 20 New England Business Center, Andover , MA01810 - 1077
Technical Abstract: Lithium ion batteries suffer from low specific capacity and capacity fade during cycling due to a range of causes.  The Physical Sciences Inc. (PSI) innovation will provide the low cost fabrication of a nanostructured morphology for metal oxide cathodes that is expected to significantly improve their performance.  While this process is applicable to most of the candidate cathode metal oxides, PSI will focus on demonstrating the utility of the process with the V2O5 system, which has promising Li intercalation capacities.  Achieving these capacities has been inhibited by crystal structure changes that occur during intercalation.  The PSI synthesis method uses a V2O5 gel precursor to produce a nanostructured cathode with projected high capacity, and discharge rates.  The cathodes produced by the PSI process are expected to exceed the performance of the benchmark LiCoO2 system, at a significantly reduced cost.  PSI anticipates cathode gravimetric capacities in excess of 300 Ah/kg, and a capacity fade of less than 10% over 300 cycles based upon improvements in published values for lithium capacity in V2O5.  This unique metal oxide production method, coupled with state-of-the-art V2O5 cathode chemistry would provide an enabling technology for rechargeable batteries for long duration space service and exploration vehicles.
Potential non-NASA applications: Rechargeable Ni-Cd batteries have been the power source for portable consumer items such as cordless appliances, power tools, digital cell phones and notebook computers.  Increasingly, however, Li-ion batteries are being phased in for these portable applications.  Li-ion batteries provide more than three times the energy density and twice the cycle life of Ni-Cd batteries and their self-discharge rate is significantly less.  The total secondary battery business is expected to exceed $10 billion per year by the year 2000, with more than 25% of that captured by Li-ion batteries.  The energy density and discharge rate enhancements that the PSI cathode technology envisions would enable a significantly larger fraction of the total battery sales to be committed to Li ion batteries.

Proposal Title: High Performance, Microfabricated Converters for Deep Space Probes
Small Business Concern_Address: Etna Rd., P.O. Box 71, Hanover , NH   03755 - 0071
Principal Investigator_Address: Etna Rd., P.O. Box 71, Hanover , NH03755 - 0071
Technical Abstract: This proposal addresses the need for the efficient conversion of thermal energy from a radioisotope heat source to electrical energy for deep-space probes.  We propose to develop a miniature Turbo-Brayton Power Unit (TBPU) in a closed-loop Brayton cycle to provide approximately 100 We of electrical power at a thermal efficiency of 38%.  The technical approach that enables high efficiency relies on unique micro-fabrication techniques that have been developed at Creare.  These techniques have been used in long-life, vibration-free turbo-Brayton cryocoolers that have been successfully space flight qualified and tested.  Here we plan to apply the basic technology to high temperature power generation.  The innovation that will be demonstrated in Phase I is the operation of the turbomachine rotor at high speeds in gas bearings and at prototypical temperatures.  We will also develop a preliminary design for a TBPU optimized for spacecraft power conversion.  In Phase II, a prototype TBPU will be developed and tested at prototypical power levels and temperatures.  Creare is uniquely qualified to succeed in this research and development program.  The project team that will collaborate on this effort has extensive experience in the development of space-flight hardware incorporating high-speed turbomachines, high-performance recuperators and precision gas film bearings.
Potential non-NASA applications: An open-cycle turbo-Brayton power unit promises to be lighter, quieter and more compact than current commercial generators.  Commercial applications include portable power units and cogeneration units for construction and camp sites; emergency power units for homes and offices; and auxiliary power units for homes, boats and aircraft.

Proposal Title: MEMS Packaging for Deep Space Environments Using Nano-structured Polymers
Small Business Concern_Address: 2302 S. Fairview Street, Santa Ana , CA   92704 - 4938
Principal Investigator_Address: 2302 S. Fairview Street, Santa Ana , CA92704 - 4938
Technical Abstract: This SBIR project will develop nanostructured network polymers for packaging micro-electromechanical systems (MEMS) for harsh environments in deep space missions.  MEMS technology enables the development of spacecraft devices and subsystems which are: (1) very small, (2) low-cost, (3) very low mass, (4) very low volume, and (5) very low in power consumption.  While MEMS devices offer major improvements in spacecraft efficiencies and new mission functionalities, MEMS also introduce new problems directly related to their micro-size and solid state structure. Space missions require devices to operate in harsh environments with: (1) extreme temperatures, (2) debris, (3) planetary atmospheres, and (4) electromagnetic radiation.  A single dust particle can upset the function of a MEMS device.  MEMS have a much higher noise floor than other technologies. Nanostructured network polymers are a revolutionary technology for producing crystalline ceramic such as diamond and silicon carbide, from a low cost polymer.  These polymers are: (1) soluble in common solvents, (2) readily applied to surfaces as coatings, (3) shape conformable, and (4) photo-etchable using conventional semiconductor lithographic techniques.  Silicon carbide, diamond, and titanium carbide ceramics can be produced that are wear resistant, vibration (noise) resistant, heat resistant, rad-hard, and chemically inert for packaging MEMS devices.
Potential non-NASA applications: Commercial Product/Service ? AMT anticipates becoming a packaging service contractor for MEMS devices in manner similar to semiconductor packaging facilities, e.g. Amkor, IPAC, etc.  Target Market Niche ? The market for MEMS devices is in the billions of dollars range and it is expected that a unique packaging technology should provide a market niche that is in excess of $100M.  Unique Aspects of the Technology for the Market Niche ? The materials to be developed for this project provide characteristics that are enabling for many MEMS applications.  The devices that are in use today are failing prematurely because of wear and thermal problems that prevent the devices from working properly.  Low cost diamond and SIC materials will provide unique benefits that will enhance the performance and durability of MEMS devices.  Importance of the Commercial Venture to AMT ? AMT is presently conducting projects and establishing a commercial business for electronics packaging and thermal management of electronics devices.  This project provides a complementary niche to the AMT business plan and will enhance our competitive position in the market for packaging electronics and other micro-scale devices.

Proposal Title: Long Life, High Energy Silver/Zinc Batteries
Small Business Concern_Address: 809 University Drive East, Suite 100E, College Station , TX   77840 - 2173
Principal Investigator_Address: 809 University Drive East, Suite 100E, College Station , TX77840 - 2173
Technical Abstract: With the highest available energy of any known aqueous chemistry, Silver/Zinc batteries have found successful application in numerous NASA missions.  However, severe wet-life and cycle life limitations of present cell designs restrict the mission capability of the Silver/Zinc system.   Two principle causes of cell failure are: 1) degradation of the cellophane separator in contact with alkaline KOH electrolyte/Ag+ ion and 2) shape change and dendrites associated with the zinc anode. The innovation proposed here applies radically new material formulations and methods of electrode fabrication to produce extremely long-life and high energy Silver/Zinc cells.  More specifically, a chemically-stable, surface-functionalized, microporous, polyolefin separator and specially formulated roll-bonded electrodes, are to be evaluated in Silver/Zinc cells.  Successful implementation could prove to be a significant advance in performance (energy and operational life) in a system with demonstrated capability to operate in harsh environments, providing a high power alternative to lithium-ion batteries.  In the proposed Phase I effort, RBC Technologies will work with Eagle-Picher Technologies to demonstrate expected improvements in silver/zinc cell energy, power and durability cells and deliver to NASA a Final Technical Report. RBC would extend this effort and deliver working batteries to NASA as part of a follow-on Phase II.
Potential non-NASA applications: Silver/zinc batteries have been widely used in space where volume and weight limitations are critical.  Space applications include: launch-vehicle guidance and control, telemetry, NASA vehicles, space shuttle payload launch and power for the life-support equipment used by the astronauts during EVA's.  Silver/zinc batteries (primary as well as secondary) also find critical applications in military markets, powering over 90% of all military missile systems, including the Patriot and Tomahawk Cruise missiles.  The Navy makes use of  silver/zinc batteries in applications that include: mines, buoys, special test vehicles, swimmer aids, deep submergence and rescue vehicles, exploratory underwater vehicles, torpedo propulsion, drones, submarines, and other military equipment.  There are also commercial sector applications for silver/zinc in premium electronic equipment that requires a lightweight, high-capacity battery, such as portable medical equipment, portable communications, and professional video recorder.  With sufficient improvements in wet-life/cycle-life, technology developed under this SBIR program could find new markets in high performance telecommunications and satellites, which are currently undergoing high rates of growth.   Higher performance silver/zinc batteries could be reasonably expected to take market share from older versions of this system, and would be a driver for implementing technology successfully developed under this program.
